title: Grand Haven approves short-term rentals in commercial district near downtown
description: The city council approved a zoning change requiring short-term rentals in the Centertown Overlay District be located above first-floor retail spaces to maintain the commercial character.
content:
The Grand Haven City Council recently approved a zoning change requiring short-term rentals in the Centertown Overlay District be located above first-floor retail spaces to maintain the commercial character. Pictured is a MLive file photo of a section of Grand Haven's Centertown on North 7th Street.

GRAND HAVEN, MI - City leaders have given final approval to allowing short-term rentals in the commercial area of a Grand Haven neighborhood bordering downtown.

The Grand Haven City Council on Monday, Aug. 18, unanimously approved the second reading of a zoning change that will allow people in the Centertown Overlay District to apply for a special land use application to operate a parcel as a short-term rental.

Centertown is the area around Washington Avenue and Seventh Street. There are 23 parcels in the overlay district, which comprises several blocks in the heart of Centertown, that are now eligible to apply for STR use.

There are approximately 350 registered short-term rental units across the city.

The city requires any short-term rental in Centertown to be an upper-level unit, as all first-floor parcels must be retail/commercial, and, if using a parking lift, it must meet city weight and size requirements.

The first reading of the zoning change was approved on Aug. 4.

Centertown resident Peter Wilson spoke at both meetings on the zoning change, expressing concern that the change was approved to benefit one developer.

In July 2024, Wilson said he spoke to the planning commission about having a short-term rental in Centertown and was told it would not be supported.

After seeing the request from local realtor John Groothuis of Capstone Companies to allow STRs in the Centertown district get approved, Wilson said he felt slighted.

“I disagree with the public-facing narrative that this is not to benefit one specific development,” Wilson said on Monday. “There are similar requests for existing properties that have been soundly rejected that may be equally or more deserving.”

The city approved a site plan on Aug. 24 for a mixed-use development by Capstone at the southwest corner of Seventh Street and Columbus Avenue.

Steinbech Crossings will be three stories, with commercial business and an enclosed parking garage on the first floor and 12, two-bedroom condos on the second and third levels.

The condos will be for sale and owners would then have the option to apply for STR use. Currently, the development’s parking plan doesn’t align with the city’s parking requirements for STRs, according to City Planner Brian Urquhart.

Wilson’s initial request was asking for more of a “broad scope,” Urquhart said, allowing STRs in Centertown beyond the central commercial area and into traditional neighborhood areas.

“That obviously did not receive a favorable response,” Urquhart said.

Several meetings were held on the matter, and an April planning commission meeting saw public comments that were “largely in favor of permitting short-term rentals,” according to city records.

Before voting Monday night, council member Kevin McLaughlin said to Wilson that if he could do the process over again, “it’d be handled differently.”

“I don’t agree with everything that went on with this whole process, but we’re just too far down the road and I can’t legitimately say no after everything that has gone on up to this point,” McLaughlin said.

Earlier this month, Mayor Bob Monetza said he wanted to make conservative changes, as the Centertown District is currently working on revamping its long-term master plan.

In updating the Centertown vision plan, the city’s goal is to have a “strategic approach to public/private development,” among other things, Urquhart said.

The plan is expected to identify strategies that would encourage infill development, repurposing existing buildings for new uses and address potential mobility and streetscape improvements.

The city is currently seeking bid proposals from planning firms to work on the Centertown vision plan. Staff plans to bring a recommendation first to the downtown development authority by September.

A technical grant from the Michigan Economic Development Corporation is expected to be in the city’s account by October, which will fund the planning process that will then start in November.

Urquhart said there will be an emphasis on public participation, feedback from stakeholders and potentially a “visioning workshop” with the community.
summary: The Grand Haven City Council has approved a zoning change allowing short-term rentals in the Centertown Overlay District, a commercial area near downtown. The change requires short-time rentals to be located above first-floor retail spaces to maintain the commercial character. The city allows 23 parcels in the overlay district that are eligible for STR use. The first reading of the zoning change was approved on Aug. 4. Concerns were raised at both meetings about the change being approved to benefit one developer and the potential for similar requests for existing properties to be granted. The move is part of the city's strategy to develop infill development into a residential area.
shortSummary: Grand Haven approved a zoning change allowing short-term rentals in the Centertown Overlay District, maintaining commercial character, despite local opposition and potential developer benefit concerns.

MUSKEGON COUNTY, MI - Muskegon County moved forward this week with plans to make paths more accessible on the south portion of Dune Harbor Park.
The 377-acre park at 3071 Lincoln Ave. in Norton Shores has miles of trails through hardwood forests, dunes and wetlands. The two inland lakes allow for kayaking, fishing and wildlife viewing. The park also fronts Lake Michigan.
The Nugent Sand Company previously operated on the site for 101 years.
Recent erosion from rainwater has made the paths and parking lot at Lincoln Avenue on the south end of the park less accessible, according to Bob Lukens, community development director.
“The erosion is pretty extensive there,” Lukens said. “We’ve done some work filling it with rock and other things but it’s not really working well.”
The Muskegon County Commission approved Tuesday, Aug. 19, seeking out developers to install curbing, ADA-parking with markings, an ADA-accessible walkway, stairs and a catch basin in the area.
The catch basin will redirect the water that’s causing erosion in the parking lot into a rain garden area.
That area will be filled with native plants that will organically clean the water before it goes into the South Lake, Lukens said.
The estimated cost of the project is $55,000 and will be covered by a $250,000 grant the county received in 2024 from the Consumers Energy Foundation.
So far, the grant funds have been used for volunteer projects and educational programming at the park.

GRAND HAVEN, MI - A park on Grand Haven’s east side is getting some major improvements this year, starting with a new playground.
All but the swing sets are being replaced at Sluka Field park’s playground, 1521 Waverly Ave.
Included in the revamp will be an ADA-accessible merry-go-round with seats, a new climbing structure and sensory toys for younger kids, said Derek Lemke, facilities and grounds manager for the department of public works in Grand Haven.
The sand box has been removed.
The playground closed on Aug. 8. It is expected to be open by this Friday, Aug. 22. If not, Lemke said it would be completed by Aug. 26 at the latest.
After the new playground is installed, new mulch will be spread on the 4,500 square-foot area.
The $51,000 project is being done by the Great Lakes Recreation Company out of Holland.
The previous playground was between 15 and 20 years old and had “reached a state of disrepair,” Lemke said.
“It had become unsafe,” Lemke said, describing rusting and peeling stairs, among other things. “We had a girl fall and cut her face last winter on it, so it’s not something that would be able to be salvaged.”
Lemke said “so many people” called his department asking if they could have or buy the old playground equipment, which he denied because of safety concerns.
Residents also asked about having a rubber surface playground, such as the one at the Imagination Station playground at Mulligan’s Hollow behind the Tri-Cities YMCA. Lemke said the “pour in place” playground service is too “cost prohibitive” to do at this time.
The neighborhood park is used by the Northwest Ottawa Recreation Authority (NORA), soccer groups, the Tri Cities Kids baseball and softball league and residents in the area.
On Sept. 8, the Sluka Field Project will start, which will involve a major renovation of the baseball diamond and park.
The dugouts will be removed and replaced with brand new, more accessible ones. There will also be a new seating area, new bleachers installed and fencing replaced around a portion of the park. There will also be new lighting, landscaping, accessible sidewalks and 22 additional parking spots.
There are currently 39 spaces and on days where there is overflow, people tend to park on an empty field that will end up being turned into more parking lot, said Dana Kollewehr, assistant city manager.
The city was awarded a $293,000 trust fund grant from the Michigan Department of Natural Resources in 2024 on the condition that the city provide an equal match to the project.
In June, the city council unanimously approved a $534,884.76 bid for Zeeland’s Midwest Construction Group. The project is expected to be complete by November.

MUSKEGON COUNTY, MI - Camping fees have been raised for the three campgrounds in Muskegon County.
The $7 daily fee increase will begin in 2026 at Blue Lake, Pioneer Park and Meinert parks, following a vote by the Muskegon County Commission on Tuesday, Aug. 19.
Blue Lake and Pioneer will increase from $38 to $45 per night and Meinert Park from $45 to $52 per night. A seasonal camping rate increase at Meinert Park from $3,000 to $3,300 was also approved.
The change will make Muskegon County park fees “more in line” with the state campgrounds, such as Muskegon State Park, Hoffmaster State Park, Holland State Park and Ludington State Park, said Community Development Director Bob Lukens.
Lukens said the state parks charge $45 per night for 20-to-30-amp service and $50 per night for 50-amp service. Some parks charge $60 for a “full hook up,” which includes water, sewer and electric.
The county last raised its camping rates two years ago by $2.
Both the community development and strategic planning committee and county commission approved the change unanimously with minimal discussion.
Commissioner and Board Chair Charles Nash emphasized that the park staff provide “quality” and “efficient” service in light of hearing recent complaints about upkeep and staff availability.
Reservations for campsites, group camping, rental cabins, picnic lodges, and shelters can be made online. There are ADA-friendly campsites available.
The first reservation day for the 2026 season will be Jan. 2.

argos_summary: Grand Haven’s City Council approved a zoning change that allows short‑term rentals only on upper floors above first‑floor retail in the Centertown Overlay District, a move that has sparked debate over developer benefits and community impact. The city also plans a mixed‑use development at Seventh and Columbus with condos that could become rentals, and a new vision plan seeks to encourage infill and repurpose existing buildings. Meanwhile, Muskegon County is investing $55,000 to address erosion and improve ADA access at Dune Harbor Park, and Grand Haven is upgrading Sluka Field’s playground and baseball facilities with a $51,000 playground overhaul and a $534,884 construction contract. Muskegon County also approved a 2026 camping fee increase to align with state rates.
